message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated opening pressure, polymorphonuclear neutrophil, protein and decreased glucose suggest bacterial meningitis. Among the options, only K capsule is a virulence factor found in some Gram-negative bacteria, including Escherichia coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae, which can cause meningitis in infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated opening pressure and elevated polymorphonuclear neutrophil suggest bacterial meningitis, and the Gram-negative rod identified on CSF culture indicates that the infecting organism has a K capsule, which is necessary for the organism to evade the host immune system and colonize. LPS endotoxin is a component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, but it is not necessary for infection. IgA protease is a virulence factor for certain bacteria that colonize the respiratory tract, but it is not necessary for meningitis. M protein is a virulence factor for Streptococcus pyogenes, which is not a Gram-negative bacterium and is not likely to cause meningitis in a neonate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Gram-negative bacteria have an outer membrane that surrounds the cell wall, called the outer membrane, which contains lipopolysaccharides (LPS) endotoxin. However, the missing option here is the K capsule, which is a structure outside the cell wall of certain bacteria that helps prevent phagocytosis by immune cells. K capsule is a virulence factor that protects bacteria from the host immune system and allows them to enter the spinal fluid and cause an infection in the brain or spinal cord.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Gram-negative bacteria have a K capsule, which is necessary for their pathogenicity. LPS endotoxin is found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, but not specific to any one type of infection. IgA protease is an enzyme that cleaves IgA antibodies and is found in some bacterial pathogens. M protein is a virulence factor found in Streptococcus pyogenes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Gram-negative bacteria can be identified by a pink-stained capsule and K capsules help them avoid the human immune system, allowing them to cause infections in vulnerable infants. LPS endotoxin can cause sepsis, IgA protease breaks down immunoglobulin A, and M protein is a virulence factor for group A Streptococcus, but none of these properties are necessary for the infection described in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The properties of the organism suggest that it is likely an encapsulated Gram-negative bacterium, which requires a K capsule for infection. LPS endotoxin can cause sepsis, but is not specific to Gram-negative encapsulated bacteria. IgA protease and M protein are properties of certain bacteria, but are not necessary for infection of this particular infant.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated opening pressure, elevated neutrophils, and decreased glucose in the CSF are consistent with bacterial meningitis. Gram-negative rods are more commonly associated with neonatal meningitis, and among the options, only K capsules are a common virulence factor of Gram-negative bacteria, allowing the bacteria to resist phagocytosis and complement-mediated killing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Gram-negative rods that cause meningitis commonly have a K capsule which is necessary for virulence and evasion of the host immune system. LPS endotoxin is also present in Gram-negative bacteria but is not specific to meningitis. IgA protease and M protein are not present in Gram-negative bacteria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated opening pressure, elevated polymorphonuclear neutrophil, elevated protein, and decreased glucose in the CSF indicate bacterial meningitis. Gram-negative rods are commonly associated with Escherichia coli (E. coli) infection, and the K capsule in particular plays a role in the virulence of E. coli in causing meningitis in neonates.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Gram-negative bacteria with K capsules are associated with meningitis in infants, and the symptoms described in the case suggest meningitis. LPS endotoxin is associated with septicemia, not meningitis. IgA protease is seen in some strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae, which can also cause meningitis but is not the cause in this case. M protein is seen in some strains of Streptococcus pyogenes, which causes strep throat and not meningitis caused by Gram-negative rods.
